The current price points are wildly high for a cozy game, with full outfits often landing in the $25‚Äì$40 range.

The only microtransaction that affects gameplay (as of December 2025) is the Founder's Pack courier pet, which lets you send 4 items to storage every 10 minutes. Late into the main questline, you can also earn a free courier pet which lets you send 4 items as well. With the amount of content the game provides for free, this is one of the few games where I feel good about buying cosmetics to support continued development.

The devs know how to make a cozy game. There's no threat of death or loss of resources. The inventory has a generous overflow system. There's very little competition between players for resources. Everything can be done at your own pace. Even tending to your garden, your plants will never die no matter how long you neglect them.

The villagers are fun and have unique personalities, even the ones I hate. There's tons of dialogue, including lines that reference quests you've done in the past and dialogue choices that you yourself have made. Gift giving feels natural as people tell you not only what they're in the need for but also what their friends or family might like as a gift.

The world feels fleshed out and fun to explore, with lots of hidden secrets. Quests are plentiful and fun. Progression has a good, satisfying pace. Mining and woodcutting are enjoyable for some mindless satisfaction. Fishing, hunting, and gardening are all fun and engaging. Cooking is engaging, but I think it needs some tweaks to feel better. Bug catching is a little lackluster in my opinion and could use a little more to make it stand out.

The animations are incredibly smooth (with some exceptions). The art style looks great. The animals are adorable! It's a visual feast.

One thing that feels like a bit of a miss is there's not a lot of encouragement to interact with other players. You do get a buff that grants potential double resources by partying up, but you have to be really close to each other to get the benefit. Other than that, there's not a lot of interaction I've seen besides people calling out rare resources in chat. In the future I'd like to see some systems that emphasize the MMO side of things a bit more.

Palia is still in beta, so things are subject to change. And because it's in beta, there's lots of bugs, mostly visual or UI-related. But as it stands right now, this game provides an absurd amount of fun for free. I have high hopes for its future.

Real cash money store prices are ridiculous, but it's (mostly) cosmetics. No pay to win yet, though there is some pay for convenience. At the time of writing, the pay-for-convenience isn't required to make the game playable (it's nothing like running speed or inventory space, for examples of other games' "optional" purchases that aren't). 

There is no threat of character death/dying in the game. If you fall off an island in the sky, you just respawn on the edge. Nothing attacks you, and none of the puzzles do damage: you don't even have a health bar. The challenges are in the form of puzzles (some jumping puzzles, not all jumping puzzles) and grind. 

The community wobbles between fantastic and really problematic. A lot of people are really nice. A minority of people participate by having self-imposed "nice" community rules that they won't explain to you, but they WILL shriek at you and insult you for breaking (when group activities spawn, you'd BETTER do it right according to them, or else).  The good news is, you can completely ignore them, and somebody will eventually explain what those other people are on about. The rules in question are reasonable, but the people trying to "enforce" them are...not, lol. 

Farming loop is very satisfying (but very limited), ranching currently sucks (my chickens are really cute tho), mining and foraging are a++++++++++++, grindy without being too grindy. Fishing is great. Cooking is...very active. Sometimes I like it, sometimes I just want to eat a stupid sandwich and wish there were a less time consuming option that wasn't drops in a bucket for my energy pool. Hunting is initially awesome but gets stupid and annoying pretty quickly. 

Decorating is good. Furniture doesn't take up space in your storage, and the crafting loop for it is enjoyable. You learn recipes by crafting other recipes in that pattern. Unfortunately there really isn't anything to DO with the furniture except use it or store it; you can't sell it or (as far as I know) give it away to other players. 

NPCs are only half a step above SDV NPCs in being fleshed out, but their tropes are fun and their quips are entertaining. Romances are questlines, and they're cute. Voice acting is consistent, from fair to good depending on the character, I haven't run into any bad voice acting at all. 

Lore is reasonably good. MSQ is unlikely to offer any surprises, but it's entertaining. 

Worth playing, worth contributing to the operating costs by way of buying an overly expensive outfit or two if you have disposable income for video games. If nothing else, grab the starter pack and/or the founders pack once you're sure you're going to stick around and play to get your money's worth out of them.

I don't typically make reviews and by no means am I a game creator or an expert. This review is mostly coming from the eyes of someone who fell in love with Palia and quickly grew to dislike it.

I'll start it out pretty simple. I was fresh to Steam and got a little bored of the handful of games I had, so I searched for new games and saw Palia. To me, it just seemed like a 3D Stardew and when I popped in the game I got hooked by the customization and achievements. (Being a completionist is the death of me lmao) If you're someone that likes to 100% games or just spend hours doing activities like catching bugs, hunting things, and maybe even fishing then this game will most likely hook you like it did to me. I actually adored Palia for the first 300 hours of my gameplay. Not only did I have all this stuff to do, but there were also communities where I could connect with people. Very rarely did I run into rude/toxic players in the in-game community. 

Now this sounds fairly positive so far, right? Wrong. 

Eventually, I joined their Discord server to get more regular updates - because that's what every lover of a game does. The big problem? There was absolutely no communication with the community at all. For a game that practically revolves around looting things you catch/hunt you would think they'd fix a bug where loot glitches into the sky/ground and you can't grab it, right? Again, WRONG. They've "fixed" it a few times and it consistently keeps coming back, not to mention the amount of times the games terrain makes bugs and huntables just straight up disapear. This might not seem like too much of a problem, but Palia has a rarity system. 

I'll use my experience as an example. There are epic bugs (currently the highest rarity of bug I believe) and you need both regular and star quality to get certain achievements. These bugs - namely Rainbow Tipped Butterfly and Fairy Mantis - can be a big pain to get. However, I got lucky. Or so I thought. I was just wandering around when I saw a star quality Fairy Mantis (The last bug I needed and one I spent a few hundred hours searching for). I caught it, and it glitched into the ground and I couldn't pick it up. I didn't find another one for about 200 hours of gameplay. 

If that wasn't bad enough, early on in my playing of Palia (We'll say January of 2025) there weren't a lot of big updates much less a roadmap or any communication on what was going on. The most we got were premium store updates which rubbed a lot of people the wrong way - I wonder why? I will say that the one bonus of Palia is that it doesn't force boosts or lock things behind money which is surprising for a free game but anyways. A few months later, we got Elderwoods. Not only that, but we got a roadmap too! Things were actually looking good. That was until these updates actually came out. Yes, I'm talking about the new housing line and the ranching system. Now this might just be my personal opinion, but they overhyped it quite a bit. This led to a lot of players being disappointed by the limited choices with the new housing line (not to mention the price of it) and how dull the ranching system actually was.

I would also like to stress just how horrible some of these achievements are. I have all but two achievements completed. The two I have left are: Pebble Plunderer (Get all pebbles and give them to Einar), and the Makeshift Collector (Obtain every makeshift item from waterlogged chests) Let's dive into Pebble Plunderer. Most of the pebbles you can find around the lands of Palia, except for the smooth pebble. For some godforsaken reason, that pebble can be obtained by random chance from oysters. I am not exaggerating when I say I've opened 2000 (maybe more) oysters and have not obtained one. There was speculation that it was bugged, but I don't believe it was ever confirmed. I disliked repetitive grinding, the only reason I could get through hunting/bug catching was because I was actively focusing on something. Running up and down the coast of Bahari for hours (Which by the way, when you step into the shallow water that is supposed to be fine, you drown. That bug has been around for months.) is not how I want to spend my gameplay. Now onto Waterlogged Chests. You can obtain these from fishing - again at random chance. Personally, I dislike fishing in games but I actually liked Palia's mechanic which is why I can sort of stand it. But again, we run into the problem of just standing there for hours and clicking away. 

Now I'm sure you could sit there and say "But Pumpki, you don't need to do all of that!" And you're 100% right, I don't. However, I have completed every quest, every board, and all of the relationships with the villagers (Which haven't been expanded in a hot minute) and like I said before, completionist. Again, I'd like to stress that I'm no game developer or expert - and some of this does come from a place of bias. But if you fall in love with a game and witness first hand just how horrible things are handled, it might rub you the wrong way too. 

This isn't to say that Palia isn't a good game. Personally I think that it's a pretty good game with a lot of potential. Most of these issues can be chalked up to poor development and poor communication. That's also not to say that the whole dev team is bad, but if you spend enough time in the community you'll most likely see that there's huge room for improvement. 

I really did fall in love with the characters, the story, and the overall design of the game. And yes, I poured many many hours of my life into it. Do I regret it? Sort of. Palia isn't the worst game out there and for free it is pretty decent, but if you're looking for something to grow attached to long-term and watch the development blossom I strongly decide against it.

TLDR: Palia is a decent game without paywalls and gives you plenty to do (If you're a completionist and like decorating/customization) but I strongly advise against growing attached or staying long-term due to the lack of communication between developers and their community (Worst I've seen so far) and the prioritization of mediocre updates over fixing long-term, sometimes game breaking bugs.

Palia starts out looking harmless and soft, but once you spend more time in it, the whole structure shows how little there actually is to do. The early moments feel fine, then the repetition creeps in, and it becomes obvious that the game leans on chores instead of anything that feels rewarding.

Progression is the biggest problem. You gather materials, feed them into tasks, wait through long timers, build a room, and then the final result barely matters. Even the house building loop feels dull. Nothing in it gives any sense of payoff. After a while, the only reasonable question is why you would keep putting energy into something that refuses to give anything back.

The clothing situation makes the everyday experience worse. Every outfit that looks remotely cute requires real money. The free clothes look like leftovers. Character style should be a fun part of a game like this, but here it feels restricted unless you pay. That takes a lot of enjoyment out of the basic presentation of your character.

NPC relationships never grow into anything interesting. You hand them gifts, watch a bar move, and end up with scenes that feel hollow. It is a friendship system without any real development. It does not matter how much time you put into it. The interpretation stays the same every time. It is just a loop.

The quests deserve their own separate analysis because they are boring as hell. They stretch out simple tasks into long sequences that feel like homework. I could not even finish them. Every objective felt like the same assignment copied and pasted into a new location. There is no momentum and no sense of progress, and the entire questline falls apart because of it.

Moving around the world highlights even more problems. You travel long distances to reach areas that contain very little. Resource spawns appear inconsistent. Sometimes you end up standing in place waiting for something to appear again. It does not feel calm. It simply feels empty.

When you put all these pieces into one conclusion, the problem becomes clear. Palia asks for time without giving any meaningful return. The world looks friendly at first glance, but the gameplay underneath feels flat and unrewarding. After enough hours, you stop trying to push the game forward because the answer becomes too obvious. There is no real point to keep going.

I will get into this a lot more below, first up the basics.

Graphics: The game adopts a cartoon-style visual approach, clean, simple, and easy on the eyes. It runs exceptionally smoothly, and the graphics never detract from the experience. In fact, the art style feels charming and laid-back, creating a welcoming atmosphere. Elements like water and trees are nicely done, though the grass foliage is quite basic. Still, given how flawlessly it performs at max settings, it's a reasonable trade-off.

Audio: The game features simple, relaxing, and calming sound design that complements the overall atmosphere well. While the music was a bit grating, I ended up turning it off, the rest of the audio is solid and fits the game's vibe nicely.

Controls: Full key rebinding is supported, and everything functions smoothly without issue. That said, the character controls can feel a bit off at times. especially during climbing, where he occasionally falls for no apparent reason. It‚Äôs frustrating when it happens, but aside from that, the controls are generally fine.

Game-play and everything else after: The game is a free-to-play, open-world life sim with light farming elements, though "open-world" is a bit generous, as the map is fairly small and it forces you to load into other areas. It's hard to pin down exactly what genre it fits into. One thing‚Äôs for sure: you‚Äôll spend the vast majority of your time running. I mean really running. It made me forget DayZ‚Äôs reputation as a running simulator, this game easily takes that crown. There are no mounts, vehicles, or fast-travel boards to get around, the fast travel to base or a town specific is limited and costs in game currencies. Movement is entirely on foot, and that‚Äôs the core game-play loop.

You do get a homestead, a private base you can build and expand. You can invite a friend to visit and even give them editor permissions, but their actions don‚Äôt affect your world, example granting editor etc and you need to build something for a mission, they do too, in you base only counts for you so you cannot work together to achieve the same common goal and have one base for both of you, which works when you play this game with a partner but this doesn‚Äôt do it that way. Co-op is limited to simply running around together. You can‚Äôt share quest progress (e.g., if a quest asks for five carrots, you both have to collect five individually), and while you can farm or mine side by side and both pick up resources, that‚Äôs about the extent of it. It‚Äôs not a true co-op experience, which is disappointing. My wife and I jumped in hoping to play collaboratively, but it ended up feeling like two solo games running in parallel. She enjoyed it to a certain point; I got bored because it‚Äôs mainly single player with added other people. 

If you and your friend has the same mission, it doesn‚Äôt matter. You BOTH have to individually complete each action, regardless if it‚Äôs the same thing. There are many games that do this a lot better. If you both have the same quest, one person can run on and complete it all without needing both people‚Ä¶ this game doesn‚Äôt do that. It‚Äôs solo with a friend to run around the world with. 

On the free-to-play side, it‚Äôs fair. It gets you in the door, and while there‚Äôs a bit of FOMO with limited-time event items, everything is cosmetic, no pay-to-win, no stat boosts. That said, the cosmetics lean heavily toward feminine styles. Most outfits seem designed with female characters in mind, and masculine options are sparse. You can wear anything regardless of gender, but it‚Äôs not uncommon to see male characters in corsets in this game due to the way the skins are positioned. The game clearly caters more to a female audience, which is fine, it‚Äôs not a bad game by any means but there are males who would like to play and look the same but a male alternative. But the co-op is bare-bones, the grind is real, and the game-play loop just isn‚Äôt for me.

The game features a range of skills, from foraging and mining to chopping trees and even capturing creatures in a Pok√©mon-style system. The more you engage with these activities, the more XP you earn, levelling up to unlock better tools and capture gear but we found this to be very grinding, spending lots of time chopping trees to barely get a level. You start with basic materials like stone and gradually work your way up, though tools do require repairs over time. It‚Äôs a decent progression system, but the repetitive grind can wear thin.

I don't typically make reviews and by no means am I a game creator or an expert. This review is mostly coming from the eyes of someone who fell in love with Palia and quickly grew to dislike it.

I'll start it out pretty simple. I was fresh to Steam and got a little bored of the handful of games I had, so I searched for new games and saw Palia. To me, it just seemed like a 3D Stardew and when I popped in the game I got hooked by the customization and achievements. (Being a completionist is the death of me lmao) If you're someone that likes to 100% games or just spend hours doing activities like catching bugs, hunting things, and maybe even fishing then this game will most likely hook you like it did to me. I actually adored Palia for the first 300 hours of my gameplay. Not only did I have all this stuff to do, but there were also communities where I could connect with people. Very rarely did I run into rude/toxic players in the in-game community. 

Now this sounds fairly positive so far, right? Wrong. 

Eventually, I joined their Discord server to get more regular updates - because that's what every lover of a game does. The big problem? There was absolutely no communication with the community at all. For a game that practically revolves around looting things you catch/hunt you would think they'd fix a bug where loot glitches into the sky/ground and you can't grab it, right? Again, WRONG. They've "fixed" it a few times and it consistently keeps coming back, not to mention the amount of times the games terrain makes bugs and huntables just straight up disapear. This might not seem like too much of a problem, but Palia has a rarity system. 

I'll use my experience as an example. There are epic bugs (currently the highest rarity of bug I believe) and you need both regular and star quality to get certain achievements. These bugs - namely Rainbow Tipped Butterfly and Fairy Mantis - can be a big pain to get. However, I got lucky. Or so I thought. I was just wandering around when I saw a star quality Fairy Mantis (The last bug I needed and one I spent a few hundred hours searching for). I caught it, and it glitched into the ground and I couldn't pick it up. I didn't find another one for about 200 hours of gameplay. 

If that wasn't bad enough, early on in my playing of Palia (We'll say January of 2025) there weren't a lot of big updates much less a roadmap or any communication on what was going on. The most we got were premium store updates which rubbed a lot of people the wrong way - I wonder why? I will say that the one bonus of Palia is that it doesn't force boosts or lock things behind money which is surprising for a free game but anyways. A few months later, we got Elderwoods. Not only that, but we got a roadmap too! Things were actually looking good. That was until these updates actually came out. Yes, I'm talking about the new housing line and the ranching system. Now this might just be my personal opinion, but they overhyped it quite a bit. This led to a lot of players being disappointed by the limited choices with the new housing line (not to mention the price of it) and how dull the ranching system actually was.

I would also like to stress just how horrible some of these achievements are. I have all but two achievements completed. The two I have left are: Pebble Plunderer (Get all pebbles and give them to Einar), and the Makeshift Collector (Obtain every makeshift item from waterlogged chests) Let's dive into Pebble Plunderer. Most of the pebbles you can find around the lands of Palia, except for the smooth pebble. For some godforsaken reason, that pebble can be obtained by random chance from oysters. I am not exaggerating when I say I've opened 2000 (maybe more) oysters and have not obtained one. There was speculation that it was bugged, but I don't believe it was ever confirmed. I disliked repetitive grinding, the only reason I could get through hunting/bug catching was because I was actively focusing on something. Running up and down the coast of Bahari for hours (Which by the way, when you step into the shallow water that is supposed to be fine, you drown. That bug has been around for months.) is not how I want to spend my gameplay. Now onto Waterlogged Chests. You can obtain these from fishing - again at random chance. Personally, I dislike fishing in games but I actually liked Palia's mechanic which is why I can sort of stand it. But again, we run into the problem of just standing there for hours and clicking away. 

Now I'm sure you could sit there and say "But Pumpki, you don't need to do all of that!" And you're 100% right, I don't. However, I have completed every quest, every board, and all of the relationships with the villagers (Which haven't been expanded in a hot minute) and like I said before, completionist. Again, I'd like to stress that I'm no game developer or expert - and some of this does come from a place of bias. But if you fall in love with a game and witness first hand just how horrible things are handled, it might rub you the wrong way too. 

This isn't to say that Palia isn't a good game. Personally I think that it's a pretty good game with a lot of potential. Most of these issues can be chalked up to poor development and poor communication. That's also not to say that the whole dev team is bad, but if you spend enough time in the community you'll most likely see that there's huge room for improvement. 

I really did fall in love with the characters, the story, and the overall design of the game. And yes, I poured many many hours of my life into it. Do I regret it? Sort of. Palia isn't the worst game out there and for free it is pretty decent, but if you're looking for something to grow attached to long-term and watch the development blossom I strongly decide against it.

TLDR: Palia is a decent game without paywalls and gives you plenty to do (If you're a completionist and like decorating/customization) but I strongly advise against growing attached or staying long-term due to the lack of communication between developers and their community (Worst I've seen so far) and the prioritization of mediocre updates over fixing long-term, sometimes game breaking bugs.

Palia starts out looking harmless and soft, but once you spend more time in it, the whole structure shows how little there actually is to do. The early moments feel fine, then the repetition creeps in, and it becomes obvious that the game leans on chores instead of anything that feels rewarding.

Progression is the biggest problem. You gather materials, feed them into tasks, wait through long timers, build a room, and then the final result barely matters. Even the house building loop feels dull. Nothing in it gives any sense of payoff. After a while, the only reasonable question is why you would keep putting energy into something that refuses to give anything back.

The clothing situation makes the everyday experience worse. Every outfit that looks remotely cute requires real money. The free clothes look like leftovers. Character style should be a fun part of a game like this, but here it feels restricted unless you pay. That takes a lot of enjoyment out of the basic presentation of your character.

NPC relationships never grow into anything interesting. You hand them gifts, watch a bar move, and end up with scenes that feel hollow. It is a friendship system without any real development. It does not matter how much time you put into it. The interpretation stays the same every time. It is just a loop.

The quests deserve their own separate analysis because they are boring as hell. They stretch out simple tasks into long sequences that feel like homework. I could not even finish them. Every objective felt like the same assignment copied and pasted into a new location. There is no momentum and no sense of progress, and the entire questline falls apart because of it.

Moving around the world highlights even more problems. You travel long distances to reach areas that contain very little. Resource spawns appear inconsistent. Sometimes you end up standing in place waiting for something to appear again. It does not feel calm. It simply feels empty.

When you put all these pieces into one conclusion, the problem becomes clear. Palia asks for time without giving any meaningful return. The world looks friendly at first glance, but the gameplay underneath feels flat and unrewarding. After enough hours, you stop trying to push the game forward because the answer becomes too obvious. There is no real point to keep going.
